bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, June 17, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] responds to Scannell's critique of his epidemiology paper.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.J. Scannell, June 17, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 17, 1923.
Dear Scannell:
div1.p:
I was glad to get your letter of June 3rd, and I hope Connor's
and Hanson's (and possibly White's) will be as constructive in their
criticisms on my Epidemiology. How the thing appears from a different
view-point is always desireable.

item.p:
1/ The only duration of life of aegypti of importance in epidem-
iology necessarily is that duration in nature: (a) the maximum for any
one insect: (b) the duration of life of such numbers as would suffice
to continue infection. The first might well be occasionally as long as occurs
in a laboratory, and an insect thus preserved might once in a while
lead to a very much belated case of yellow fever.

(B) Naturally depends upon the critical number of at that time and place aegypti--i. e. on
the number of susceptible and unsusceptible men in a community their distribution

At Iquitos this seemed to be about six weeks--the same length of
time is obtainable from an analysis of Connor's report of Guayaquil. I
was able to fix the time more definitely than either at Paita, having
the advantage of working under closer conditions. In a community where
there was a large number of susceptible people the chance is that this
time would be somewhat longer than either myself or Converse observed it.

list.item:
2/ And here is where you helped me: In the script of the Epidemio-
logy I wrote “in no collection of water with ‘exclusively earth’ (mud)
‘sides’ at the surface of the water.” I struck out “mud”, because I
thought earth in contact with water would naturally be considered mud.
I am going to return to my original statement. I am quite sure that it
is the consistency of the container at the surface of the water rather
than its material that affects ovaposition. A hardened hollow in wood

ashes would be perfectly suitable as would burnt earth.

3/ It is reasonable to believe that the limits of viability of the
causative organism might well be different from, and less than, those of
its insect host. For malaria this is certainly the case; (a) the parasite
dies from an exposure much less than that which killes the Anopheles
carrying it and (b) does not develope in the insect at some temperatures
at which the insect is functionally active--although here the difference
in temperature limits is slight.

For the first, however, one must note that Anopheles hibernates as
imago and aegypti does not, or if so for only a very short time. This
would prevent this part of the analogy from having much, if any, weight.

I considered saying something about this in the Epidemiology, but did
not, because we have no sufficient data on this subject and I purposed to
include in it only proven things. There are a number of instances in
which the temperature (outside) has fallen well below 60°F (some below
50°F) in which yellow fever has continued quite vigorously after it rose
again. This happened at Memphis in /97 after moderate frost. Of course
it would be impossible to say to what temperature the mosquitoes that
carried on this infection were exposed, many of them being sheltered in
houses, but I doubt if it was not well below 80°F. Immediately after
the cold weather there was practically a cessation of yellow fever,
which recrudesced, and indeed increased, in a week or ten days. The
picture (and inference) was as if the function of the agency infective
to man was suspended by the cold, but not destroyed, or even much less-
ened when the temperature rose again.

Admitting the causative relation of the L. icteroides and that 80 F.
is the optimum temperature for their culture, we do not know in what form
they exist in the insect and it may well be that in this stage they may
be able to live at a temperature below that necessary for development.
development.
This is true of the plasmodium malariae, both tertian and falciparum.

The epidemiological evidence, as far as it goes, implies (I do
not say proves) that the insects retain their infection --not necessar-
ily their infectivity--under almost any conditions that enable them to
live.

Experimentally the question could be readily settled by human exper-
iments. Expose a few aegypti known to be infective to man to X° Centi-
grade (X°C. being low enough to suspend functional activity of the in-
sects, but not to kill them) and see if they are still infective when
the temperature is raised again. Guinea pigs could be used, of course,
but their infection by aegypti seems to be so uncertain that a very large
number of observations would be needed to establish a negative result.

The only epidemiological evidence on this matter which I can think
of as readily obtainable would be to see whether in nature the geographi-
cal limits of the propagation of yellow fever (i. e. of “infectable ter-
ritory”) corresponds to that of functionally active aegypti. If the in-
sects are functionally active in a place known to be non-infectable there
are three hypotheses:

(a) They mightwere not be in sufficient numbers to convey yellow fever
with the chances that they have had:

(b) The parasite does not at the temperature of that place undergo
the development (Noguchi would say the increase) in the mosquito neces-
sary to render her infective or
(c) The parasite dies in the mosquito.

Subjecting mosquitoes which had fed on a sick man at the place in
question to a higher temperature after feeding and determining their in-
fectivity would settle between (b) and (c).

Petropolis, Brazil; and the City of Mexico might give you data on
this subject.
subject.

Fernando Lopez found that in their laboratory--apparently not heated--
aegypti were functionally active--although slow in their life processes--
in Mexico City, which I think we have a right to call non-infectable
territory. Are they found there, L'coaga said not, & if so to what extent,

I think, however, I will insert a foot note in the Epidemiology,
when published, calling attention to this matter and, naturally, men-
tioning you as suggesting it.

4/ I have from the beginning been inclined (possibly because very de-
sireous) to accept the causarive role of L. icteroides and have done so
since Feb./20, when Noguchi published his differentiation between this
organism and Icteroides haemorrhagica (by cross Pfeiffer and immune re-
actions). It is (See Page 5)
is
5
fair to say, however--as I did for the Nelson Loose-Leaf people--that
this is “generally, but not universally accepted.” Neither Welch of
Hopkins nor Rosenau of Harvard regard it as established and I confess
I would myself be better satisfied were the mosquito conveyance experi-
ments more satisfactory. I feel like discounting the opposition of
Guiteras--for whose opinion I have in general the very highest regard--
because I doubt the technique with which the experiments with this or-
ganism have been made by the Havana school. I could wish much that he
(Guiteras) and they could get in such personal touch with Noguchi as
to have the matter settled, at least as between them.

By the way, a recent description by a Dr. Perrin of the histo-path-
ology of the liver in yellow fever would. I think, not be accepted by
Darling: Russell or da Rocha Lima as distinctive. This last, as you
know, gave his name to the inter“mid- zonal necrosis”; in general characteristic
of yellow fever.

With very best remembrances, in which Laura, who is writing this
